I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The focus of the capacity development technical assistance (TA) is consistent with the 
aims of the Government of Fiji’s public sector reform program and ADB’s Pacific Approach 
2010–2014, which accords priority to improved public sector management in the region.1 A TA 
fact-finding mission visited Fiji from 1–8 September 2011 and reached an understanding with 
the  government  and  other  stakeholders  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2    
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  For more than a decade, Fiji has experienced low rates of economic growth, negligible 
job creation, and consistently high levels of poverty. The poverty incidence was estimated at 
35.2% of the population in 2009, far above Fiji’s Millennium Development Goal target of 14.7% 
by 2015.3 Moreover, nearly half of the population could be considered to be poor or near poor, if 
those with incomes near the poverty line are included. Poverty reduction challenges include 
high dropout rates in basic education; low participation rates in postsecondary education; a 
lifestyle-induced rise in noncommunicable diseases; the lack of access to clean drinking water 
and modern sanitation facilities by a large segment of the population; the growing numbers of 
families that reside in urban squatter settlements; and the low levels of expenditure on, and poor 
coverage of, social safety net programs. Per capita incomes in Fiji have declined steadily from 
2001 to 2011. Economic growth, has averaged –0.3% per annum since 2006, which is far below 
what is needed to meet Fiji’s poverty reduction targets. 
 
3.  Fiji’s state-owned enterprises (SOEs) are a major impediment to both economic growth 
and poverty reduction. The SOEs absorb scarce government funding, use capital inefficiently, 
raise costs, and impede effective delivery of basic infrastructure services. Low productivity of 
SOE investment is a significant hindrance to economic growth. 
 
4.  SOEs make up a significant proportion of Fiji’s economy—there are 29 SOEs with 
combined assets of $845 million dollars (22% of gross domestic product); two of these are in 
liquidation.4 The government’s SOE portfolio represents close to 20% of Fiji’s total economic 
assets. The average return on assets for SOEs in 2002–2009 was 0.4%, and the average return 
on equity was 0.8%.5 In 2002–2009, SOEs generated profits of just $18.6 million, which was 
less than the $23.6 million the government injected into loss-making SOEs. Returns on private 
investment in 2008 were nearly seven times higher than returns on SOE investments.  
 
5.  The government recognizes the urgent need for reform, and has launched a program of 
SOE divestment, corporatization, and outsourcing of SOE functions to the private sector. The 
government has an explicit SOE reform strategy for 2010–2012, which is estimated to cost 
$13.6 million to implement. The following SOE reforms have been implemented: (i) the merger 
of Fiji Ships and Heavy Industries into Fiji Ports Corporation in 2009, (ii) corporatization of the 
Water  and  Sewage  Division  of  the  Ministry  of  Public  Utilities  into  a  commercial  statutory

authority (Water Authority of Fiji) in 2010, (iii) corporatization of the Quarantine Department (to 
Biosecurity Authority of Fiji) and Fiji Islands Maritime Authority (to Maritime Safety Authority of 
Fiji), (iv) the restructuring of the Fiji Sugar Corporation, and (v) establishment of an outsourcing 
council. Efforts are ongoing to divest the government’s holdings in other SOEs, including the Fiji 
Meat Industry Board, Food Processors Fiji, and Post Fiji. 
 
6.  Nonetheless, implementation of the planned SOE reform agenda has been delayed by a 
series of institutional and budgetary constraints. There is no detailed implementation plan for the 
SOE reform strategy to guide and sequence specific reforms. The government is unable to 
attract skilled persons for senior civil service positions, with the result that these positions are 
increasingly  filled  with  personnel  that  lack  the  expertise  needed  to  design  and  oversee 
technically complex and contentious SOE reforms. The government’s efforts to reform SOEs 
have  also been  weakened  by  frequent  changes  in  senior  civil servant  positions.  Financial 
resources are limited, and several SOEs will require financial restructuring. There are high 
expectations regarding implementation progress and associated near-term gains, despite the 
challenges faced, and increasing recognition that target dates for completion must be pushed 
back.    
 
7.  Acceleration of SOE reform can significantly contribute to growth and poverty reduction. 
Better SOE service provision in areas such as power, water, and telecommunications can bring 
essential services to the poor and improve their livelihoods. Commercialization and privatization 
of  SOEs  will  boost  opportunities  for  private  sector  development.  SOE  reform  will  bolster 
productivity  throughout  the  economy,  and  facilitate  growth  and  job  creation.  Better  SOE 
performance is expected to reduce the need for government subsidies and budget transfers and 
allow redirection of savings to other priority areas for government expenditure.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be higher rates of economic growth and poverty reduction and improved 
provision of services. TA performance will be monitored through achievement of fiscal and 
enterprise performance targets for SOE reform contained in the government’s reform program. 
The outcome will be strengthened SOE reform planning, management, and implementation 
capacity  in  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  and  the  Ministry  of  Public  Enterprises, 
Communication, Civil Aviation, and Tourism (MPECCAT). The achievement of this outcome will 
be reflected in reduced budgetary demands and declining levels of contingent liabilities from 
SOEs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will address a fundamental constraint to the effective implementation of SOE 
reforms,  i.e.,  the  lack  of  technical  capacity  among  key  public  sector  managers  in  central 
agencies of the government to design and manage SOE reforms. The TA will build on ADB’s 
significant history of support for SOE reforms in Fiji to (i) support MOF and MPECCAT in 
preparing  a  coordinated  and  sequenced  SOE  reform  implementation  plan;  (ii) support  the 
implementation  of  pilot  SOE  reforms;  and  (iii)  facilitate  an  effective  SOE  reform  steering 
committee. 
 
10.  Output 1: preparation of a coordinated and sequenced state-owned enterprise 
reform implementation plan. The government’s SOE reform strategy will be reviewed by the

3
SOE reform steering committee (to be chaired by the permanent secretary for MPECCAT, and 
comprising the permanent secretaries for MOF, Ministry of Strategic Development, National 
Planning and Statistics, and Public Service Commission, and a representative from the Solicitor 
General’s Office). Staff of MOF and MPECCAT, supported by the TA, will serve as the steering 
committee’s secretariat. Based on the review, the committee will identify policy and technical 
gaps,  constraints  to  implementation  and,  where  appropriate,  will  realign  and/or  reprioritize 
reform priorities. Reforms that have the best potential to bring about significant benefits to low-
income households in terms of job creation and/or more efficient provision of basic public 
services will be prioritized and recommended for cabinet endorsement. Support will then be 
provided for developing an implementation road map that will pilot actions from the strategy that 
can be replicated across the various SOEs. The implementation road map will include policy 
frameworks  and  good  practice  guidelines  for  reorganization,  corporatization,  increased 
commercialization, partial and full privatization, and outsourcing. 
 
11.  Output 2: Pilot state-owned enterprise reforms. One SOE will be selected as a pilot 
for reform. It is expected that this SOE will be restructured and prepared for privatization. There 
are valuable lessons in restructuring and divestiture to be gained from this experience.     
 
12.  Output  3:  An  effective  state-owned  enterprise  reform  steering  committee. 
Institutional capacities for SOE reform will be developed. A needs assessment will identify 
capacity development requirements. Based on the identified needs of MOF and MPECCAT 
staff, a capacity development road map will be developed and implemented (primarily through 
on-the-job training). This approach builds on lessons from previous ADB assistance to support 
SOE  reform  implementation  in  the  Pacific,  and  in  Fiji  in  particular,  which  points  to  the 
importance of capacity building and development through on-the-job coaching, informal training 
sessions, workshops, and seminars. 
 
13.  SOE  reforms  can  be  contentious  and  will  require  strong  leadership  within  the 
government.  Risks  to  implementation  include  (i)  changes  in  the  government’s  SOE  policy 
direction; (ii) external shocks, which could divert government’s attention from SOE reform; (iii) 
limited  government  capacity,  and  staff  changes; and  (iv)  stakeholder  resistance  to  reform. 
These  risks  are  compounded  by  the  restrictions  on  public  consultation  and  open  debate 
established by the amended Public Order Act, 2012; both public consultation and open debate 
are essential to building broad ownership of SOE reforms. 
 
14.  These  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  (i)  coordinated  oversight  of  the  TA  and  the 
implementation of key tasks by the SOE reform steering committee; (ii) cabinet endorsement of 
outputs 1 and 2; (iii) close management of the TA by ADB at the field level; and (iv) an 18-month 
implementation period to ensure that the appropriate building blocks for long-term capacity 
building are put in place. Consultations with nongovernment stakeholders will be arranged and 
facilitated by the steering committee in compliance with the amended Public Order Act. More 
importantly, there is broad-based domestic support for SOE reforms. These reforms have long 
been a priority, as evidenced by (i) inclusion of specific policy measures in successive national 
development plans and national budgets; and (ii) the results of consultations with a wide range 
of public and private sector stakeholders prior to TA preparation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The government has requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office

4  
accommodation, office supplies, and secretarial assistance. Details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The executing agency will be MOF, and both MOF and MPECCAT will be implementing 
agencies. The government will form the SOE reform steering committee to coordinate TA 
activities and track implementation progress. At present, ADB is the only development partner 
assisting  in  SOE  reform.  The  TA  consultants  will  liaise  with  relevant  development  partner 
programs  and  projects  working  in  complementary  areas  to  ensure  a  coordinated  and 
harmonized approach to economic policy reform. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months (May 2012–October 2013) and will provide 
17 person-months of international and 6 person-months of national consulting services. The 
consultants will work as a cohesive team and comprise an SOE specialist and team leader 
(international,  8  person-months);  a  capacity  development  expert  (international,  3  person-
months); a sector specialist (international, 6 person-months), and a local facilitation specialist 
(national, 6 person-months). 
 
18.  The consultants will be engaged through a firm based on a simplified technical proposal 
under the quality- and cost-based selection process, using a 90:10 quality–cost weighting in 
light of the highly technical and complex nature of the activities. The consultants will be engaged 
according to the ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in 
accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
19.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the TA, and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, 
lessons, and next steps. Throughout the TA, the team leader will submit brief monthly progress 
reports  summarizing  TA  activities,  progress,  issues,  and  constraints.  Team  members  will 
produce reports on their respective activities for incorporation in the team leader's progress and 
final reports. The draft final report will be submitted at least 5 weeks prior to the end of the 
assignment, and finalized within 2 weeks of receipt of comments from the government and ADB. 
 
20.  TA progress will be monitored using performance targets described in the design and 
monitoring framework (Appendix 1). ADB will assist the government in sharing all reports with 
other development partners. These will be disseminated through roundtable meetings, radio 
interviews, and the ADB website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Fiji for Implementing Reforms of State-Owned Enterprises, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultant services will support the technical assistance (TA). The team leader will be a 
state-owned enterprise (SOE) specialist and will supervise all consultants and lead the work on 
the TA. Consultants are expected to work together to ensure that TA is delivered in line with the 
intended scope and that subprojects are coherent. 
 
2.  The consultants will work as a cohesive team to deliver the tasks below. The TA will be 
implemented by a team of three international consultants (total of 17 person-months) and one 
national consultant (total of 6 person-months). The international consultant team will comprise 
an SOE specialist acting as team leader (8 person-months); a capacity development expert 
(3 person-months); and a sector specialist (6 person-months). These will be joined by a local 
facilitation specialist (national, 6 person-months). 
 
A.  Team Leader and State-Owned Enterprise Reform Specialist (international, 
8 person-months, intermittent) 
3.  The specialist will have extensive experience in public sector reform across a range of 
technical  and  political settings.  The  specialist  must  have  (i) strong,  demonstrated  political, 
negotiation,  and  process-facilitation  skills;  (ii)  a  demonstrated  ability  to  effect  change  in  a 
manner that takes into account the social and political constraints of Pacific Island settings; and 
(iii)  a  practical  understanding  of  the  needed  consultative  and  participatory  processes.  The 
specialist will undertake a joint secretariat role to the SOE reform steering committee chaired by 
the permanent secretary for the Ministry of Public Enterprises, Communication, Civil Aviation 
and Tourism (MPECCAT). 
4.  Tasks will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  Review the government’s current SOE reform program to ensure alignment with 
the government’s economic and political strategic focus and identify any potential 
social impacts. Update the reform program to ensure inclusion of (a) elements 
that  address  reorganization,  corporatization,  increased  commercialization, 
outsourcing,  privatization,  rationalization,  and  regulation;  and  (b) 
recommendations to strengthen the management and financial positions of SOEs 
that  remain  under  government  ownership,  so  they  can  meet  the  principal 
objective of SOEs as set out in the Public Enterprise Act, 1996. In undertaking 
this task, the specialist should be cognizant of and guided by lessons from 
previous  assistance  to  SOEs  in  Fiji,  the  broader  Pacific  context,  and  the 
principles of SOE reform set out in Schedule 1 of the Public Enterprise Act. For 
SOEs  in  which  privatization  is  considered  the  optimum  outcome,  develop  a 
privatization pipeline. 
(ii)  Develop a detailed SOE reform implementation road map that will identify priority 
or first-order activities and outcomes of the strategy that can be used as pilot 
activities and outcomes to build understanding and capacity within MPECCAT 
and the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to assist in full implementation of the strategy 
by  the  government.  Reforms  that  have  the  best  potential  to  bring  about 
significant benefits to low-income households in terms of job creation or more 
efficient  provision  of  basic  public  services  should  be  prioritized.  The 
implementation  road  map  is  to  be  approved  by  the  SOE  reform  steering 
committee and endorsed by cabinet.

Appendix 3  9 
(iii)  Prepare  policy  frameworks  and  good  practice  guidelines  for  reorganization, 
corporatization  and  increased  commercialization,  partial  and  full  privatization, 
and outsourcing. 
(iv)  Work  closely  with  the  capacity  development  expert  to  understand  capacity 
constraints within MOF and MPECCAT that may impact upon the proposed TA 
inputs and propose a short-to-medium term approach for sustainable capacity 
development in SOE reform. This will include assisting the capacity development 
expert to implement training, seminars, and conferences. Part of this review will 
involve  considering  the  advantages  and  disadvantages  of  the  continued 
separation of SOE ownership monitoring between MOF and MPECCAT, and 
making  recommendations  on  restructuring  the  monitoring  units  if  the  review 
shows this would be beneficial. 
(v)  Support the local facilitation specialist in the conduct of a public awareness 
campaign, public consultation, and information dissemination on key aspects of 
the TA. 
(vi)  Identify key points where change will need to be managed and then design 
specific interventions to support the management of change. 
(vii)  Support the sector specialist and work with those SOEs that are being reformed 
under the TA to enable a smooth change to reformed status. 
(viii)  Provide oversight and overall guidance to the work of the sector specialist. 
(ix)  Assist  in  any  other  tasks  to  ensure  successful  implementation  of  the 
government’s SOE reforms. 
(x)  Prepare required TA reports using input from team members.  
 
B.  Capacity Development Expert (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). 
 
5.  The expert will have a background appropriate to undertake the tasks listed below, and 
be efficient in facilitation and education. The expert will have at least 10 years of experience 
providing  similar  advice  to  a  variety  of  Pacific  governments  and  societies  and  have 
demonstrated  strong  political,  negotiation,  and  process  facilitation  skills.  Knowledge  of 
ownership monitoring, assessment of what constitutes competency in the context of ownership 
monitoring, and the ability to develop plans to improve competency levels (including setting 
development plans and targets) are essential. A practical understanding of consultative and 
participatory processes is also required. 
 
6.  Tasks will include but not be limited to the following. 
(i)  Undertake,  with  the  support  of  the  SOE  specialist  and  in  concert  with  the 
ministries concerned, a participatory diagnostic analysis of those areas of the 
asset management unit of MOF and MPECCAT relevant to the TA, including 
consideration of capacity dimensions at the individual, organizational, and inter-
organizational levels. The outcome will be an analysis of the advantages and 
disadvantages  of  the  continued  separation  of  SOE  ownership  monitoring 
between  MPECCAT  and  MOF,  and  recommendations  on  restructuring  the 
monitoring units if the review shows this would be beneficial. 
(ii)  Reach an agreement with the permanent secretaries for MOF and MPECCAT on 
the necessary areas for capacity development—a capacity development road 
map—and restructuring subject to the outcome of the review in item (i). 
(iii)  Provide a framework for ownership monitoring capacity development and training 
in areas identified in the initial diagnostics, including a monitoring framework to 
measure the impact of individual interventions and baseline competency levels 
for the various capacity development areas. The expert will take the lead in

10  Appendix 3 
designing and implementing training, seminars, and conferences based on the 
areas identified in item (i). 
(iv)  Lead and undertake capacity development activities agreed under item (ii) and 
included in the framework developed under item (iii). 
(v)  Identify opportunities for MOF and MPECCAT to access capacity development 
opportunities supported by other development partners. 
(vi)  Provide input for TA reports, as requested by the team leader. 
 
C.  Sector Specialist (international, 6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The  specialist  will  possess  a  degree  (or  equivalent  qualification)  in  accounting  or 
business and will have at least 10 years experience in a senior management position in the 
relevant sector. The relevant sector will be determined following preparation of the SOE reform 
implementation road map. The specialist will have the capability to undertake a comprehensive 
analysis of the financial aspects of an organization, among others.  
 
8.  The  specialist  will  have  strong  administrative  abilities  and  exceptional  leadership 
qualities. Ideally the specialist will have current knowledge and understanding of the SOE 
operating in the identified sector, and a broad understanding of the government’s policies and 
position on reforming the SOE. In addition, the specialist should be sensitive to Fiji’s cultural and 
political-economic context. 
 
9.  Specific responsibilities will be determined following finalization of the SOE reforms 
implementation road map. General responsibilities will include working with the team leader to 
undertake an economic and financial analysis of the SOE involved in the sector and advise and 
make recommendations to the SOE reform steering committee and the SOE board on an 
appropriate  reform  strategy  that  could  include  (i)  reorganization,  corporatization,  increased 
commercialization, outsourcing, privatization, and rationalization; and (ii) recommendations to 
strengthen the management and financial positions of SOEs that remain under government 
ownership and can meet the principal objective as set out in the Public Enterprise Act. Specific 
tasks could include the following: 
(i)  Report to the SOE board on overall coordination, organization, management, 
direction, and supervision of the reform plan. 
(ii)  Develop business and operational plans for the consideration and approval of the 
SOE board. 
(iii)  Assist in the implementation of activities to achieve the objectives of the business 
and operational plans. 
(iv)  Propose cost-effective strategies to achieve profitable operations, including right-
sizing,  review  of  conditions  of  service,  management  of  cash  flow,  improved 
revenue  collection  and  minimization  of  expenditures,  effective  delivery  of 
services and management of SOE staff.  
(v)  Update the financial information of the SOE. 
(vi)  Undertake a detailed needs analysis to critically review all aspects of the SOE’s 
operations to improve its viability over the short and long term, in parallel with 
other improvements and sector-wide reforms.  
(vii)  Provide milestone and output reports to the SOE reform steering committee and 
SOE board, including but not limited to (a) reviews of the present situation, 
including issues and challenges; (b) a financial analysis of the SOE (including 
input to cabinet memoranda on recommended strategies for improving viability); 
and (c) a nonfinancial analysis and recommended strategies (including input to 
cabinet  memoranda  on  nonfinancial  strategies  such  as  restructuring  and

Appendix 3  11 
downsizing). The work of the specialist will be evaluated through assessment of 
these required reports. 
(viii)  Assist in the successful implementation of the approved reform strategy. 
(ix)  Take action to mitigate risks that will threaten the success of the inputs and 
ensure that all risks are identified and assessed (with appropriate strategies 
developed to overcome them) during coordination meetings and in all progress 
reports. 
(x)  Provide input for TA reports, as requested by the team leader. 
 
D.  Local Facilitation Specialist (national, 6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
10.  The local facilitation specialist will have a strong background in training and education 
and consultative and participatory processes, as well as extensive experience in technical 
assistance in those fields in Fiji. 
 
11.  Tasks  to  be  carried  out  under  the  guidance  of  the  team  leader  or  specialists  and 
advisors will include but not be limited to the following. 
(i)  In concert with other team members, conduct public awareness campaigns and 
information dissemination on key aspects of the TA work. 
(ii)  Assist MOF and MPECCAT and the consulting team in any necessary public 
consultation related to the TA. 
(iii)  Assist in any other tasks to ensure successful implementation of the TA. 
(iv)  Provide input for TA reports, as requested by the team leader. 
 
E.  Reporting Requirements 
 
12.  An inception report will be prepared for ADB and the government by the team leader 
within 8 weeks of the start of field activities. It will include the SOE reform implementation and 
capacity development road maps. Quarterly progress reports will be submitted throughout the 
TA, and a draft final report completed by August 2013. The final report is to be submitted within 
a month of the incorporation of ADB comments on the draft final report.
